talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Construction, upon notice:

item.para: 1 ) What was the year in which the original construction of Hobart Airport commenced and what was the cost.
What is the present estimated cost of the Hobart Airport at present under construction.
What is the justification for demolishing the previous construction.

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

item.para: It is assumed that the honourable senator's question relates to the terminal building rather than to the overall Hobart Airport. Work commenced on the construction of the original Hobart Airport terminal building in 1956 and was completed in 1958. The cost of the building and associated services was £93,000.

The estimated cost of the terminal building at present under construction is $1,440,000. A separate Flight Services Building was recently completed at a cost of $88,400 and provides for the replacement and expansion of the Flight Services facilities previously incorporated in the original terminal.

The existing terminal was inadequate in size and design for the bigger passenger loads of the DC9 and Boeing 727 airliners. In order to accommodate the forecast daily peak hour of at least 3500 passengers and visitors expected at Hobart terminal by the early 1980s, an enclosed terminal area of approximately 2 Vi times that of the original terminal is required.

answer.para: The most economical way to provide a terminal of the required size and functional layout, at the same time making best use of the existing aircraft aprons, car parks and roads, and enabling airline operations to continue throughout the construction period with minimum interruption, was to construct a new single-storey building in several stages. The work was best undertaken by constructing part of the new terminal at one end of the original building, transferring terminal activities to this part on its completion, followed by demolition of the original structure and its replacement with the remaining portion of the new terminal in a way to ensure the functional and architectural integration of the completed facility.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice:

item.para: Did a deputation from the Sydney Yugoslav community, which Senator Mulvihill introduced to the AttorneyGeneral several weeks ago, express concern at the rising pressures developing from ultra right wing elements in the Croatian section of the community.
Were these demonstrated by events at the Olympic Park, Melbourne and the Sydney Sports Ground.

talk.start.para: - The Attorney-General has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

item.para: 1 ) To the best of my recollection, members of the deputation expressed concern at what were alleged to be actions committed by a section of the Croatian community in Australia. I do not recall the use of the phrase 'ultra right wing elements' but I understood them to be referring to a section whom they would regard as ' right wing '.

I am informed that at soccer matches in Sydney and Melbourne when the visiting Yugoslav team Velez Mostar played an Australian team and Victorian team respectively there were acts of violence and the game at Olympic Park in Melbourne was abandoned by the referee before full-time and that, as a result of these incidents, 1 person was convicted in Victoria and 3 persons were convicted in New South Wales. I understand that on each occasion the persons charged were arrested by the State Police.

The Commonwealth Government strongly disapproves of all acts of violence or lawlessness including those in ethnic groups. In co-operation with State Governments, the Commonwealth Government will, within the limits of its powers, take appropriate action to prevent unlawful activities of this nature.

The Australian Government Publishing Service does not pay printers accounts directly for printing purchased on behalf of Government departments. Invoices are received by AGPS and after checking for contractual conformity are passed to the department concerned for payment. The department then certifies that goods have been received and forwards the invoice for payment by the Treasury.

It is believed most of these accounts would be cleared by departments and paid within three weeks. Accounts in dispute take longer to clear, depending upon the speed with which contractors supply required information.

talk.start.para: -On 24 March 1976 (Hansard page 723) Senator Archer asked Senator Cotton, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning the Commonwealth Government's position with regard to the North West Regional Water Scheme. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer have now supplied the following information for answer to the honourable senator's question.

question.para: There are at present a number of matters affecting Tasmania which are of special concern to the Commonwealth and which were the subject of discussions held recently between the Prime Minister and the Tasmanian Premier. Those discussions encompassed the question of future Commonwealth assistance to the North West Regional Water Scheme. The Premier indicated during the discussions that legislation would be introduced to compel participation in the Scheme by all municipalities involved, even though the ratepayers of the two most populous council areas, Burnie and Devonport, had expressed significant opposition to the Scheme. The Prime Minister indicated to the Premier that the Commonwealth could not be a party to that kind of compulsion and in those circumstances there would be a need for local agreement to the proposal before the Commonwealth could consider providing financial assistance to it.

A further point to be made is that the Commonwealth's involvement in the project was on the basis of an original estimated cost of $ 10m. The new estimate of $ 17m would, in any event, have made necessary a review of the nature of the Commonwealth's assistance to the project.
